references: We follow the convention of representing the random variables using uppercase letters such as Sğ‘†S, representing the particular values they take on using lowercase letters, and representing the support of random variables using copperplate such as sğ‘ s and ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}. The distributions are represented using uppercase letters such as Fğ¹F and Pğ‘ƒP, and the probability density functions are represented using lowercase letters such as fğ‘“f and pğ‘p. For continuous distributions Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q over â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n}, the Kullback-Leibler divergence is defined as KL(P||Q)=âˆ«p(x)log(p(x)/q(x))dx\text{KL}(P||Q)=\int p(x)\log(p(x)/q(x))dx, where pğ‘p and qğ‘q denote the probability densities of Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q. The Jensen-Shannon divergence is a smoothed version of the Kullback-Leibler divergence, which is defined as JS(P||Q)=12[KL(P,M)+KL(Q,M)]\text{JS}(P||Q)=\frac{1}{2}\left[\text{KL}\left(P,M\right)+\text{KL}\left(Q,M\right)\right], where M=(P+Q)/2ğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘„2M=(P+Q)/2. The total variation distance between Pğ‘ƒP and Qğ‘„Q is TV(P||Q)=supAâŠ‚â„n|P(A)âˆ’Q(A)|\text{TV}(P||Q)=\sup_{A\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}}|P(A)-Q(A)|. See Table 1 for detailed descriptions of notations.
